defect.para: This Recall applies to 1552SC stripped chassis models built 11/03/1995 through 08/21/1996 with hydraulic brakes.

A plugged brake line that will not transmit fluid to the front or rear brakes and possible missing brake pads, could cause the vehicle to pull to the right or left when applying the brakes and/or could result in a significant increase in vehicle stopping distance. This defect could cause a vehicular accident without warning which could result in personal injury or property damage, or both.
The single customer involved will be notified of this campaign on their vehicles by Navistar.

svcsubproc.title: CHECKING FOR BRAKE FUNCTIONING PROPERLY
svcsubproc.para: It will require 2 persons to perform this Operation.

step1.para: Jack up all four wheels on the vehicle and secure with jack stands.

Have one person apply brakes while other person attempts to rotate each of the four wheels. Make sure wheels cannot be rotated. If any wheel can be rotated, it is an indication that hydraulic pressure is not getting to the brake caliper. Inspect hydraulic lines to determine if a line is plugged and a connector line is missing.

While the vehicle is in the air, visually inspect all four wheels for inboard and outboard brake pads. The outboard pad is visible through the wheel handhold unless, on dual rears, the handholds are not aligned. In that case, it is possible to feel the end retainer flange on the outboard pad, if in place.
If any brake pads are found to be missing, inspect for damage to rotor and caliper piston and replace parts as necessary.

note.para: If a brake line is required, the line should be ordered by description direct from AmTran by calling Randy Wolfe at phone number (501 327-7761. If a brake pad is found missing, all parts required should be ordered through the normal process.

entry.para: Inspect for brake system integrity and brake pads
Inspect and replace hydraulic lines and fittings
Inspect and replace front brake pad
Inspect and replace rear brake pad

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward. The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair the vehicle as soon as possible.
